fields.headline: 20 years after the discovery of the human genome, dangerous gene myths abound
fields.standfirst: Misleading rhetoric has fuelled the belief that our genetic code is an ‚Äòinstruction book‚Äô ‚Äì but it‚Äôs far more interesting than that
fields.trailText: Misleading rhetoric has fuelled the belief that our genetic code is an ‚Äòinstruction book‚Äô ‚Äì but it‚Äôs far more interesting than that, says science writer Philip Ball
fields.body:
Twenty years ago, the science journal Nature published the first draft of the human genome: the sequence of chemical ‚Äúletters‚Äù on the gene-bearing DNA of our chromosomes. The Human Genome Project (HGP) had laboured for a decade to read this coded information. In a White House press conference in 2000, Francis Collins, , who led the project as director of the US National Human Genome Research Institute, waxed biblical, calling the human genome ‚Äúour own instruction book, previously known only to God‚Äù.

The HGP has huge potential benefits for medicine and our understanding of human diversity and origins. But a blizzard of misleading rhetoric surrounded the project, contributing to the widespread and sometimes dangerous misunderstandings about genes that now bedevils the genomic age.

So far, there have been few attempts to set the record straight. Even now, the National Human Genome Research Institute calls the HGP an effort to read ‚Äúnature‚Äôs complete genetic blueprint for building a human being‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äúbook of instructions‚Äù that ‚Äúdetermine our particular traits‚Äù. A genome, says the institute, ‚Äúcontains all of the information needed to build and maintain that organism‚Äù. But this deterministic ‚Äúinstruction book‚Äù image is precisely the fallacy that genomics has overturned, and the information in the genome is demonstrably incomplete. Yet no one associated with genomic research seems bothered about correcting these false claims.

In an area as full of promise and peril as genomics, clear communication is essential. The ability to sequence our full complement of genes has enabled some great strides in medicine, but it hasn‚Äôt yet been as transformative as initially promised. Successes in gene therapy remain rare, and medicine tailored to people‚Äôs individual genetic constitution has not yet materialised. Meanwhile, a deterministic view of genes has helped arguments about eugenics and ‚Äúinnate‚Äù racial characteristics to re-enter public discourse. The first gene-edited babies were born in 2018 through a case of scientific misconduct that landed the Chinese scientist responsible for the work, He Jiankui, in prison. Meanwhile, genome-sequencing companies such as 23andMe seduce us with the shallow promise to analyse the DNA in your saliva to reveal ‚Äúwhat makes you, you‚Äù.

Gene hype has been with us ever since James Watson apocryphally claimed in his 1968 book The Double Helix that his collaborator Francis Crick told all and sundry in a crowded Cambridge pub that ‚ÄúWe have found the secret of life!‚Äù shortly after the pair figured out the chemical structure of DNA in 1953. In 1995, sociologists of science Dorothy Nelkin and Susan Lindee argued that DNA had become a scientific surrogate for the soul, a kind of mystical essence imprinted in a molecule. By reading the ‚Äúlanguage in which God created life‚Äù, as President Bill Clinton bombastically said of the HGP in 2000, it seemed that we were on the verge of understanding life at its most fundamental level.

Many geneticists say the story has turned out to be rather more complicated than they anticipated: genes aren‚Äôt quite what we thought (in fact, there‚Äôs no consensus about what they even are). Yet plenty remain happy to propagate the misleading idea that we are ‚Äúgene machines‚Äù and our DNA is our ‚Äúblueprint‚Äù. It is no wonder that public understanding of genetics is so blighted by notions of genetic determinism ‚Äì not to mention the now ludicrous (but lucrative) idea that DNA genealogy tells you which percentage of you is ‚ÄúScots‚Äù, ‚Äúsub-Saharan African‚Äù or ‚ÄúNeanderthal‚Äù. Such genetic nativism is catnip to the far right. Watson himself, one of the prime advocates of the HGP, has suggested (without credible evidence) that there may be a genetically based average difference in IQ between racial groups.

The HGP deserves a share of the blame for such problems, having promoted and sustained a misleading view of genes. When the project began, an earlier notion that human traits such as hair colour or cognitive abilities each had a dedicated gene no longer looked tenable. All the same, scientists thought genes and traits could be readily matched, like those children‚Äôs puzzles in which you trace convoluted links between two sets of items. That misconception explains why most geneticists overestimated the total number of human genes by a factor of several-fold ‚Äì an error typically presented now with a grinning ‚ÄúOops!‚Äù rather than as a sign of a fundamental error about what genes are and how they work.

Related: ‚ÄòThe wondrous map‚Äô: how unlocking human DNA changed the course of science

It‚Äôs now clear that traits such as height, as well as susceptibilities to many common ailments such as type 2 diabetes, cancer and heart problems, have a genetic component that is immensely complicated. Perhaps hundreds of genes might be involved, each with only a tiny influence. Environmental or simply random factors matter too. As a result, it‚Äôs often hard to identify effective genetic targets for drugs, and there‚Äôs little value in doing so if we don‚Äôt know how a particular gene actually influences health conditions.

There have been some successes in genetic medicine. Some drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, one of which is now being studied as a potential Covid treatments, arose from genome studies that identified two possible target genes. But the most common drugs for this condition, such as TNF inhibitors, didn‚Äôt rely on genetic data at all. Even for diseases that have a clear genetic component, genes might not be the appropriate level to intervene. ‚ÄúIn some instances,‚Äù a group of experts in genetic medicine wrote in 2013, ‚Äúan approach that is anchored in human genetics may slow down a drug discovery programme.‚Äù

The real value of the HGP isn‚Äôt in answering questions about ‚Äúwhat a gene does‚Äù, but rather showing how tiny variations in the genomic sequence of each one of us gives rise to the tremendous variations in human attributes. There is, of course, no single ‚Äúhuman genome‚Äù at all ‚Äì we each have our own. By analysing the genome sequences of hundreds and thousands of people, it becomes possible to pick out which are the tiny differences that make us different. One message of such studies is that ‚Äúrace‚Äù is a social construct not rooted in biology: there is much more genetic variation within conventional racial groupings than between them.

These comparisons of many genomes rely themselves on perhaps the most important bounty of the HGP: the sequencing technology itself. The rapid genome analysis that has made it possible for the Covid-19 Genomics UK Consortium to identify and track new coronavirus variants is just one of the benefits of the ever cheaper, faster sequencing technology developed as a result of the project. By the same token we can hope soon to know more about how our own genetics affects our individual susceptibility to severe Covid.

As well as offering such valuable resources and technologies for healthcare, the HGP paradoxically revealed the limitations of a gene-centred view of life. We don‚Äôt come with instructions included after all: you are not programmed into your chromosomes. Life is not a readout of genes ‚Äì it‚Äôs a far more interesting, subtle and contingent process than that.

  • Philip Ball is a science writer. His latest book is The Modern Myths: Adventures in the Machinery of the Popular Imagination

All the same, scientists thought genes and traits could be readily matched, like those children‚Äôs puzzles in which you trace convoluted links between two sets of items. Perhaps hundreds of genes might be involved, each with only a tiny influence. Environmental or simply random factors matter too. As a result, it‚Äôs often hard to identify effective genetic targets for drugs, and there‚Äôs little value in doing so if we don‚Äôt know how a particular gene actually influences health conditions. There have been some successes in genetic medicine. Some drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, one of which is now being studied as a potential Covid treatments, arose from genome studies that identified two possible target genes. But the most common drugs for this condition, such as TNF inhibitors, didn‚Äôt rely on genetic data at all. By the same token we can hope soon to know more about how our own genetics affects our individual susceptibility to severe Covid. fields.headline: Northern Ballet: Dangerous Liaisons review ‚Äì more sedate than seductive
fields.standfirst:
Sadler‚Äôs Wells, London
The plot convolutions of De Laclos‚Äô classic novel, and a shortage of real passion, hold back David Nixon‚Äôs adaptation
fields.trailText: The plot convolutions of De Laclos‚Äô classic novel, and a shortage of real passion, hold back David Nixon‚Äôs adaptation
fields.body:
Name recognition is important for ballet companies: make a ballet of a familiar story, get bums on seats, stay afloat. But that doesn‚Äôt mean a known title always makes a good ballet. Northern Ballet‚Äôs David Nixon first tackled Pierre Choderlos de Laclos‚Äô epistolary novel Les Liaisons dangereuses in the 90s, and he‚Äôs not the only choreographer to do so ‚Äì some thought Liam Scarlett‚Äôs version one of his best ballets.

You‚Äôd think all that romping and decadence would be a no-brainer, but the convolutions of the plot, especially those involving letters passed from one person to another that we‚Äôll never read, are hard to fathom despite Nixon‚Äôs attempts at giving pointers in the voiceover introduction. The prevailing attitude, as exemplified by the Abigail Prudames‚Äô Marquise de Merteuil, is aloof and manipulative, to coolly one-dimensional effect.

With a synopsis at hand, you‚Äôll discover that the Marquise and her ex-lover Vicomte de Valmont (Joseph Taylor) are planning various seductions, merely for sport, involving the virginal C√©cile Volanges (Rachael Gillespie), the married Madame de Tourvel (Antoinette Brooks-Daw) and Matthew Koon‚Äôs Chevalier Danceny; the latter‚Äôs naive enthusiasm ruined by the Marquise‚Äôs ploys, but Koon‚Äôs bright presence and darting jumps always a pleasure for the audience.

The first act‚Äôs scene-setting is sedate rather than bodice-ripping, probably what 17th-century aristocratic life was really like (when you want it to be more like Nicholas Hoult‚Äôs court in The Great). Vivaldi‚Äôs Four Seasons forms the soundtrack, played live. There‚Äôs no denying the greatness of the music, but there‚Äôs a reason choreographers now tend to favour more cinematic scores that help narrate the action.

Things hot up in the second act when real feelings get involved. Brooks-Daw has the best part as the virtuous, strong yet vulnerable De Tourvel, the only one emotionally invested from the off. Nixon is a good dance-maker, often finding interesting ways to start a phrase, and he sews some motives into the steps, like Taylor‚Äôs Valmont demonstrating many different ways to throw a woman in the air, tossing Gillespie aggressively or carefully holding Brooks-Daw aloft like a thing of wonder. But while some moments cut through, there‚Äôs not enough real passion or tangible plot to seduce.

  • At Sadler‚Äôs Wells, London, until 10 June. Birmingham Royal Ballet perform Contemporary Cuts at Sadler‚Äôs Wells, 11-12 June.

fields.headline: Loki episode one recap: Tom Hiddleston‚Äôs time-loop saga is beautiful, surreal TV
fields.standfirst: Clearly inspired by Mad Men, Marvel‚Äôs stunning Disney+ series kicks off as the god of mischief finds new, glorious purpose and Owen Wilson‚Äôs Agent Mobius enters the fray
fields.trailText: Clearly inspired by Mad Men, Marvel‚Äôs stunning Disney+ series kicks off as the god of mischief finds new, glorious purpose and Owen Wilson‚Äôs Agent Mobius enters the fray
fields.body:
Spoiler alert: this blog is for people watching Loki on Disney+. Do not read on unless you have watched episode one.

Hello and welcome to the Loki recaps. I‚Äôll be picking through each episode of the latest Marvel/Disney+ series as I did with The Falcon and the Winter Soldier and doing my best to find hints and clues for what lies in store for Loki and the wider MCU.

Seconds out

Let‚Äôs start at the beginning, which makes the most sense at this point. Loki is all about time ‚Äì time management, alternative timelines, time travel, time looping ‚Äì so things might get complicated if we did it any other way.

The episode opened in 2012 after the battle of New York first seen in Avengers Assemble, then revisited in the time-heist section of Avengers: Endgame. We‚Äôre spared a full rerun, but as almost anyone watching will know, Loki goes on to take the Tesseract during the kerfuffle with Tony, Ant-Man and Thor, vanishing into a portal, thereby creating an alternative timeline and version of himself. A version of himself that didn‚Äôt go on to inadvertently cause Frigga‚Äôs death in Thor: The Dark World (lucky him, skipping out on that one), or fight alongside his brother and earn a shot at redemption in Thor: Ragnarok. And perhaps most importantly for the purposes of this series, he didn‚Äôt get his neck snapped by Thanos at the start of Infinity War, either.

After a brief interaction with the Time Variance Authority ‚Äì the sterile, omnipotent body charged with preserving the sacred timeline, as decreed by the Timekeepers ‚Äì Loki is repeatedly beaten, rewound and pelted with home truths by agents including Wunmi Mosaku‚Äôs Hunter B-15 and Owen Wilson‚Äôs Agent Mobius.

At this point, it looks highly likely that the on-screen chemistry between Tom Hiddleston and Wilson will be Loki‚Äôs most powerful weapon. As Mobius showed Loki his past misdeeds on a big screen and gently probed for explanation while already being in full possession of the facts, he earned Loki‚Äôs trust, while making him see that he wasn‚Äôt born to rule, but is merely around to help others realise their potential. Mobius also posited the notion that Loki has done so many terrible things not because he enjoyed it, or because he‚Äôs the god of mischief, but because he has to ‚Äì because it‚Äôs part of his illusion, ‚Äúa cruel, elaborate trick conjured by the weak to inspire fear‚Äù. Self acceptance, identity and destiny, dealt with in the space of a scene. And to think people believe these shows are just CGI fights.

That‚Äôs not to say Loki will be without those. Responding to yet another TVA situation, Mobius travelled to a church in 16th-century France, where he encountered a young boy who pointed to a stained glass window seemingly depicting the devil when asked who had committed the latest time atrocity. Throughout WandaVision, Mephisto was expected to make his MCU debut, but it never came to pass. That image in the glass looks distinctly like the extra-dimensional demon, but Hiddleston has said Mephisto rumours are unfounded. Of course, he would say that. Or is Mobius right that the variant he needs help catching is Loki himself? Those horns do look like Loki in full Asgardian regalia, as seen in Avengers Assemble.

Overtime

After phase one of the films, Marvel landed on the idea that superhero films work best when they‚Äôre not superhero films at all, but genre movies that happen to have superheroes in them ‚Äì something that, in my book, makes reductive arguments about Marvel‚Äôs output seem more inaccurate with each passing film. Captain America: The Winter Soldier, for example, is a 70s conspiracy thriller (it even stars Robert Redford, as if to hammer the point home). Black Panther is, by his own admission, Ryan Coogler‚Äôs take on a Bond film, while Ant-Man is a heist caper, Captain Marvel is the MCU‚Äôs version of an 80s actioner in the Top Gun mould, and so on.

It‚Äôs an idea carried over on to the small screen, too, with WandaVision being an avant-garde supernatural sitcom hybrid. Here, the writers Eric Martin and Bisha K Ali appear to be trying to answer the question: ‚ÄúWhat would Marvel‚Äôs Hitchhiker‚Äôs Guide to the Galaxy look like?‚Äù A beautiful, surreal, mid-century modern bureaucratic nightmare designed by Dieter Rams is their answer. And I simply can‚Äôt wait for more.

Further minutes

  • The DB Cooper snippet was perfect. Loki‚Äôs mid-air bifrosting was in the trailer, presumed to be part of some death-defying, pivotal-to-the-plot action sequence. But no, it was a little joke stating that Loki was DB Cooper, the unidentified man who, in 1971, hijacked a Boeing 727 over the US, demanded $200,000 (which he collected), before parachuting from the plane and disappearing. The FBI only closed its investigation in 2016. I enjoyed this playful subplot, not least because it nods to Mad Men, a clear stylistic influence on Loki, and the fact that armchair sleuths theorised Don Draper was DB Cooper for some time before that show‚Äôs finale.

  • Whether you enjoyed this episode or not (I loved it, if you can‚Äôt tell), it‚Äôs hard to argue with its aesthetic beauty. I‚Äôm now scrolling through images of the Atlanta Marriott Marquis, which doubled as the TVA HQ.

  • Let‚Äôs salute the British talent on display here, Hiddleston, Mosaku and Gugu Mbatha-Raw, who will hopefully have a bigger part to play as the series goes on.

  • I could easily sit through an entire season of Marvel explainers drawn in that Friz Freleng/Pink Panther style. In fact, I could probably watch just about anything.

  • I thought the infinity stones being used as paperweights as a demonstration of the TVA‚Äôs power was a masterstroke; the thing that finally made Loki see that what he‚Äôd been craving all along was futile.

What did you think? Do you enjoy the premise? What does ‚Äúfine Asgardian leather‚Äù feel like? Was that Mephisto hiding in the church window? Have your say below in the comments

fields.headline: German election poll tracker: who will be the next chancellor?
fields.standfirst: Find out who is leading the polling to succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor of Germany
fields.trailText: Find out who is leading the polling to succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor of Germany
fields.body:
Germans will vote on Sunday 26 September to elect a new Bundestag, or federal parliament. The result ‚Äì after coalition negotiations likely to involve two or three parties ‚Äì will decide who will succeed Angela Merkel, who is standing down after 16 years as chancellor.

Some recent polls have put Germany‚Äôs Green party in the lead, as Merkel‚Äôs successor at the conservative CDU, Armin Laschet, struggles to inherit her appeal. German federal elections are proportional, so the share of vote given by polling companies should be read as translating fairly directly into share of seats in the resulting parliament. Only parties with less than 5% of the national vote, or less than three directly elected constituency seats, are not awarded proportional parliamentary seats.

Possible coalitions

German political commentary has conventional names for potential coalitions, including GroKo for the ‚Äúgrand coalition‚Äù of CDU and SPD. A possible CDU-FPD-Green coalition is referred to as ‚ÄúJamaica‚Äù because the party colours are more or less those of the Jamaican flag. For consistency, these coalitions are simulated using the latest polling averages as above. But depending on how many votes go to small parties that do not cross the 5% threshold for seats in parliament, the bigger parties may get slightly more seats than their vote share suggests.

Because coalitions are the norm in Germany, most are possible, but the other parties have traditionally said they would not enter coalition with the AfD, and there has never yet been a federal coalition involving Die Linke.

Sources and methodology

Polling data is taken from Wahlrecht.de. Then the Guardian calculates an unweighted 14-day moving average, featuring only the latest poll from each of seven pollsters within the 14-day period.

‚Ä¢ This article was amended on 25 May 2021. An earlier version erroneously stated that parties obtaining less than 5% of the national vote need to win at least one constituency seat to be awarded proportional parliamentary seats. The correct number is three constituency seats, this has now been corrected.
